Appendix  - Patient information following staff/other patient exposure to your blood or body fluids. ........................................................................................................ 45

APPENDIX7 : Needle-stick, Sharps or Splash Injury Risk Assessment Form ............ 47 APPENDIX 8: SHARPS MANAGEMENT AUDIT TOOL ................................................... 51 APPENDIX 9: Preliminary Equality Analysis ................................................................. 53
Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (hereafter referred to as the Trust) is committed to ensuring safe practice by effective sharps management in accordance with the Health and Safety (Sharps Instruments in Healthcare) Regulations

The primary risk posed by a contamination injury to NHS employees is exposure of the worker to blood borne viruses (BBV). This includes clinical and non-clinical support staff - porters, domestics, maintenance staff and ground staff. The main viruses concerned are: hepatitis B (HBV), Hepatitis C (HCV) and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).

NHS employees may acquire a BBV infection if they are exposed to infected blood or body fluids. This could be either visa the mucous membranes (eyes, inside of the mouth and nose), through broken skin or through an inoculation injury route, where the skins is punctured or scratched by a needle or sharp device that has been used in a medical procedure. (HSE, Needle-stick injuries).
Rarely patients may also have an exposure incident whilst under the care of the Trust.
A sharp is any item that is capable of penetrating the skin.
In addition this policy addresses existing requirements of the Trust in relation to the Health and Social Care Act 2008– Criterion 8 regarding safe handling and disposal of sharps.

Sharps are responsible for a significant number of injuries to staff each year. The correct use, handling and disposal of sharps will help to reduce the risk of injury and the acquisition of blood-borne viruses by both staff and patients. For the purpose of this policy the term “sharps” includes items such as needles, scalpels, razor blades, broken glass and any other sharp items that may cause a penetrating injury, laceration or puncture to the skin.

It is well documented that needlestick, sharps or other incidents involving exposure to blood and body fluids from patients poses a hazard to the health of Health Care Workers (HCW). Although the risk of acquiring blood borne viruses (BBV's) through occupational exposure is low, the consequence can be serious (Department of Health 2006). It is essential therefore that all potential exposures are rapidly risk assessed and effectively managed.

Many exposures result from a failure to follow recommended procedures, including the safe handling and disposal of needles, syringes and other sharps, not wearing protective equipment such as eye wear where indicated. However there will always be occasions where exposure occurs, despite careful attention to the correct procedures.
The main concern is the transmission of:
Hepatitis B;
Hepatitis C;
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).
In addition an exposure to body fluid can be through:
Broken skin e.g. abrasions, fresh cuts, eczema, psoriasis;
Contamination of mucous membranes e.g. lining of eyes, nose or mouth;
A human bite through mucus membrane exposure if the bite penetrates the skin.
Purpose
The purpose of this policy is to provide clear instruction on safe use, handling and disposal of sharps to ensure healthcare workers:
Are aware of actions and precautions required to minimise or prevent the risk of a sharps injury;
Reduce as far as reasonably practicable the risk of exposure to blood borne viruses through needle-stick, sharps or other incidents involving exposure to blood or body fluids;
Ensure best practice is maintained to for assembly, storage and disposal of sharps bins;

Are aware of the procedure to be followed by staff in the event that they sustain an inoculation/sharps injury or have been exposed to blood or body fluids following incidents of bites, scratches or splashes;
Are aware of the procedure for testing the patient's blood and detail the support available to staff following an incident.
Scope

This policy applies to any member of staff, who may be at risk of exposure to sharps/inoculation incidents and/or exposure to blood or body fluids via bites, scratches or splashes of blood or body fluids.
Adherence to this policy is the responsibility of all staff employed by the Trust, including agency, locum, volunteer and bank staff contracted by the Trust.
Definitions

table_items.text: ‘Sharps' devices/equipment is a clinical term for devices with sharp points or edges that have the potential to puncture or cut skin. Examples of sharps include: Needles: Hollow needles used to inject drugs (medication) under the skin & suture needles Syringes: Devices used to inject medication into or withdraw fluid from the body Lancets: Instruments with a short, two edge blade used for acquisition of blood for testing. Lancets are commonly utilised in the treatment of diabetes. Auto injectors: (including epinephrine and Insulin pens Infusion Sets: Tubing systems with a needle used to deliver drugs to the body Connection needles/sets: Needles that connect to a tube used to transfer fluids into and away from the body. This id generally used for patients on home haemodialysis. Cannulae. Giving sets (including bag and its contents). IV tubing with needles attached. Scalpel blades. Scissors and razor blades. Used or empty glass/plastic ampoules or medication. bottles.
A sharps injury is defined as an injury where a needle or other sharp object, including bones or teeth, contaminated with blood or any other body fluid penetrates the skin.

Contamination is defined as the transference of possible infection from one object to another such as splash or direct contact from blood / body fluids mucous membranes (eyes, nose, mouth) or broken skin (abrasion, cuts, eczema).
Control of substances hazardous to Health
Any device which incorporates a needle that has a safety mechanism device in place to prevent a sharp injuries.
Exudates from burns or skin lesions
Any other body fluid containing visible blood, Including saliva in association with dentistry
Bleeding gums in association with bites

data.text: NHS Constitution

The Trust is committed to: Designing and implementing services, policies and measures that meet the diverse needs of its population and workforce, ensuring that no individual or group is disadvantaged.

This Policy supports the NHS Constitution as follows: The Trust aspires to the highest standards of excellence and professionalism in the provision of high-quality patient care that is safe, effective and focused on patient experience; in the planning and delivery of the clinical and other services it provides; in the people it employs and the education, training and development they receive; in the leadership and management of its organisations; and through its commitment to innovation and to the promotion and conduct of research to improve the current and future health and care of the population.
Duties
The Health and Safety Committee chaired by the Director of Estates and Facilities is responsible for reviewing and receiving reports on, and monitoring compliance in relation to sharps safety issues.
6.1.1  Infection Prevention and Control Committee
The main duties of the Infection Prevention and Control Committee (IPCC) include:

Overseeing compliance with national standards/targets in relation to the prevention and control of Healthcare associated infections (HCAI), including the Health and Social Care Act 2008, and the Care Quality Commission (CQC);
To oversee the Trust's compliance with the CQC Fundamental Standards;
Overseeing key Infection Prevention & Control issues in relation to:
o Policy development and review;
o Audit;
o Education & training;
o Communication with staff, patients and the public;
o The monitoring of IPC incidents;

o Post Infection Review (PIR) cases, highlighting lessons learnt and action planning, ensuring that robust plans for the management of outbreaks of infection are in place and to monitor their effectiveness;
o Agreeing the annual IPC report and work programme prior to its submission to the Quality Assurance Sub-committee;
o Informing the Quality Assurance Sub-committee of clinical risk issues relating to the Trust;
o To monitor compliance for IPC training.
Duties of Individuals within the Trust
All staff working on Trust premises, outreach clinics and community settings including Trust employed staff, contractors, agency and locum staff are responsible for adhering to this policy.
Duties Are:

6.2.1 The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has management systems in place to enable the effective and safe implementation of this policy, for this policy in particular this extends to establishing and maintaining IPC arrangements across the organisation. This responsibility is delegated to the Director of Infection Prevention and Control and the person with the lead responsibility is the Director of Nursing and Quality.

6.2.2 The Trust Board of Directors are responsible for having policies and procedures in place to support best practice, effective management, service delivery, management of associated risks and meet national and local legislation and/or requirements in relation to IPC issues. The Board of Directors also monitor infection episodes, outbreaks and trends as reported by the Infection Prevention and Control Committee.
6.2.3 Consultant Microbiologists are medical microbiologists whose main duties include:
Being available for  hour access, arrangements made through local service level agreements;
Informing the IPC team of any alert organisms, conditions or notifiable diseases that may potentially cause outbreaks of infection and/or are identified as multi drug resistant organisms;
Providing expert microbiology and IPC advice for the management and treatment of micro-organisms including outbreaks of infection;
Advising on antibiotic policy/prescribing and challenge inappropriate practices;
Undertaking mandatory surveillance of HCAIs and reporting as required to PHE via a national HCAI Data Capture System.
6.2.4 Director of Infection Prevention and Control and/or Clinical Nurse Specialists Infection Prevention and Control main duties include:
Providing expert professional advice on control measures, delegating responsibility to Trust staff as appropriate;
Providing education on the prevention and control of infection to other professionals, multi-disciplinary groups, patients and carers;
Leading in the investigation of identified cases of infection/alert organisms and conditions;
Undertaking PIRs for micro-organisms as and when directed by the Department of Health;
Contributing to serious incidents (SIs) reports as required;
Notifying the local PHE Team and Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) of any outbreaks of infection.
6.2.5 The Infection Prevention and Control Team (IPCT)
The IPCT have responsibility for the co-ordination, production, updating and monitoring of this policy (refer to section 6 and Appendix 7). The IPCT is also are responsible for
ensuring all staff are made aware of this policy and advising ward staff on control measures, providing them with the necessary advice.

6.2.6 Clinical Directors /Associate Clinical Directors have responsibility for Infection Prevention and Control standards and performance within their units. Clinical Directors /Associate Clinical Directors work closely with the Matrons and support their role by ensuring that all necessary actions are implemented within their Directorates to ensure 100% compliance in audits of infection prevention and control and practice.
6.2.7 Service Managers/Modern Matrons duties include:
Membership at the IPCC where nominated by their care group;
Monitoring and on-going compliance with this policy for areas within their control and reporting non-compliance to the DIPC via the IPC team;
Reporting all matters relating to IPC to the Deputy Director of Nursing;
Facilitating feedback of information related to surveillance data and identified cases of infection/alert organisms and conditions.
6.2.8 Ward/Department Managers duties (for areas under their control are that staff) include:
Can demonstrate compliance with this policy;
Undertake mandatory IPC training;
Discuss IPC during annual service reviews and demonstrate documented evidence of this.

6.2.9 All Staff are personally accountable for actions and omissions in their practice and must always be able to justify their decisions as set out in the relevant codes of conduct. They have the responsibility to familiarise themselves with the guidance to ensure that they are competent regarding the management, safe use, disposal and adhere to safe working practices of sharps to deliver safe care to their patients in order not to harm either themselves or others.
Main Procedural Document Points (Process)

The regulations (see references) state; that ‘where medical devices provide a risk of sharps of injury a formal risk assessment (refer to Appendix 2) should be undertaken' by the manager of the service. The exposure should be eliminated if possible and if unable to be eliminated, the safest type of equipment/ medical device should be used. Therefore all staff must beware of risk assessments that are in place prior to carrying out a procedure which has a risk of exposure.

7.1.1 The Trust has fully supported the introduction of syringe devices, with engineered safety mechanisms to reduce incidents of needlestick injuries. Trust staff are expected to use devices with engineered safety mechanisms, when using any device which involves a sharp needle. Needles that do not include a safety mechanism should only be used in exceptional circumstances according to the MSE Medicines Management Policy and a risk assessment has to be completed before use.
Hierarchy of Control / Risk assessment associated with risk of Sharps

7.2.1 The Management of Health and Safety Regulations requires Trust managers to assess risks to their employees. Since the usage of sharps involves unavoidable risks the risk assessment must take account of cost benefit analysis when sharps instruments are utilised.

7.2.2 The Health and Safety (Sharps Instruments in Healthcare) Regulations requires Trust to put in place arrangements to prevent and reduce occurrence of sharps injuries and exposure incidents. This can be achieved via application of the Hierarchy of controls and principles of prevention frameworks. The Hierarchy of controls focuses on the most effective measure of removing the hazard first, rather than relying on training, behavioural or changes to work practises and the use of protective equipment. Used alongside risk assessment (refer to Appendix 2), the hierarchy provides a framework for reducing the risks of injury.
HIERACHY OF CONTROLS
ELIMINATION OR SUBSTITUTION  MOST EFFECTIVE (e.g. Eliminate unnecessary injections)

data.text: The  Health  &  Safety  (Sharp  Instruments  in  Healthcare)  Regulations    have brought into force the requirements of European Council Directive 2010/32/EU. The provisions of these regulations are summarised below:
Avoid the unnecessary use of sharps.
Use safer sharps (incorporating protection mechanisms).
Prevent the recapping of needles.
Place secure containers and instructions for safe disposal of medical sharps close to the work area.

Provide information to employees on risks, legal duties and good practice associated with sharps  equipment  usage.  In  addition  to  information  regarding  vaccination  and  support arrangements in place for injured employees.
Provide training to employees on safe use and disposal of medical sharps and safe sharps devices  and  Trust's  sharps  injury  management  process,  health  surveillance  and  other procedures.
Trust's arrangements for reporting and investigation of all sharps injury accidents
Trust's arrangements for treatment and follow-up of a sharp injury.
Regular review of sharps equipment procedures.

7.3.1 In reality it will be difficult to eliminate all sharps from health care environments. The next effective step will be to utilise engineering controls that include safe sharp devices using innovative designs to limit the risk of injury. A combination of measures may also be necessary, for example, a safe sharp device should only be introduced alongside training in its use.

7.3.2 The 5 steps risk assessment model (HSE, 2006) may be deployed as a useful method to approach a sharps risk assessment (This process is outlined within Appendix 1 and facilitated within sharps risk assessment template form provided in Appendix 2).

7.3.3 A risk assessment must be completed on all areas in which ‘safer sharp' devices cannot be implemented due to service requirements or design restrictions etc. All risk assessments conducted must consider specific control measures for mitigation of risk (refer to Appendix 2-4 for
risk assessment process, selection of safe sharps device considerations and a template risk assessment form).
Staff undertaking procedure involving sharps
7.4.1 Those carrying out venepuncture procedures must always consider using a Vacutainer first.
7.4.2 Take a sharps bin fitted with a plastic tray to point of use and dispose of sharp immediately after use (refer to Appendix 3).
7.4.3 Do not keep needles and syringes in pockets.
7.4.4 Needles must not be resheathed
7.4.5 In exceptional circumstances, if resheathing CANNOT be avoided, use a specific needle resheathing / removing device
7.4.6 Needles must not be bent or broken by hand.
7.4.7 Dispose needles and syringes as a single unit-do not remove the needle.
7.4.8 Primed syringes must be stored with great care when there is a delay in administering a drug
7.4.9 Unsheathed needle and syringe combinations or other sharps must never be passed from one person to another.
7.4.10 Sharps must never be left on procedure trolleys, on the procedures sterile towel or in any other uncontrolled location
7.4.11 When transporting a blood gas syringe, remove the needle using a removal device and attach a hub prior to transport.
7.4.12 Help should be sought when using sharps with a confused or agitated patient.
7.4.13 Ensure prior to using an engineered safety needle that staff are competent in using them.
7.4.14 Blunt needles are to be used for drawing up medications to prevent the use of sharps where they are not necessary.
Body fluids which pose a risk of blood borne virus infection

7.5.1 As it is not always possible to know who may have certain bacteria or viruses when dealing with blood and body fluids, standard infection prevention and control precautions apply in all dealings with blood and body fluids.
7.5.2 In addition to blood, the following body fluids also pose a high risk of blood-borne virus infection:
High risk body fluids are:
Amniotic fluid;
Vaginal secretions;
Semen;
Human breast milk;
Cerebrospinal fluid;
Peritoneal fluid;
Pleural fluid;
Pericardial fluid;
Synovial fluid;
Exudative or other tissue fluid from burns or skin lesions/wounds;
Saliva in association with dentistry;
Unfixed tissues and organs;
7.5.3 Other body fluids pose a risk only if they are visibly blood-stained:
Urine;
Faeces;
Saliva;
Sputum;
Sweat;
Tears.
7.5.3  Care should still be taken as the presence of blood is not always obvious. The following factors are associated with increased risk of occupationally acquired blood borne infection:
Deep injury;
Visible blood on the device which caused the injury;
Injury with a needle which had been placed in the source patient's artery or vein;
Injury with a hollow bore needle;
Terminal HIV-related illness in the source patient.
Preventative advice to staff
It is recommended that healthcare staff who handle sharps or are exposed to blood/body fluids are offered Hepatitis B vaccination.
Selection Of Safety-Engineered Devices

7.7.1 ‘Safer sharps' incorporate a built-in safety feature within their design, which is intended to reduce the risk of sharps injury. Safe sharps devices are manufactured with either an integrated safety feature which is part of the basic design of the device and cannot be removed, or a passive safety feature which does not require the user to activate it, and remains effective before, during and after use.

7.7.2 Regulatory arrangements for prevention of sharps injuries within the Trust and healthcare sector is concerned with reducing and eliminating number of ‘sharps' related injuries which occur within healthcare. Its basic guidance is:
If a sharp instrument is to be used, then a non-sharp alternative is to be sourced and used;
If a non-sharp alternative is not available, then a safety device is to sourced and use;
If a safety device is not available then all available risk management processes should be employed such as sticky mats, sharps bins, required assistance, safety procedures, training.

7.7.3 If a risk assessment indicates that there could be potential injuries leading to blood-borne infections because a hazard cannot be eliminated, the Trust will (where posiible) provide non-sharp alternatives and/or medical devices that incorporate safety-engineered protection mechanisms.

7.7.4 Devices can be passive or active. For example, passive devices have an automatic safety mechanism that is activated after use, such as when a cannula is withdrawn from a patient's vein. An active device needs to be manually activated by the member of staff.

data.text: Non-sharp alternatives
7.8.1 A filter straw (quill) or blunt needle should be used to draw up medication and fluids where a needle would normally be used.

7.8.2 A filter straw (a sterile long, thin plastic tube) is best for large volumes of liquid, and the blunt filter needle (a needle like construct with a blunt end and wide bore) for smaller amounts in ampoules.

7.8.3 As a standard safety measure, needles used for aspirating from ‘break neck' glass ampoules should have a filter built in or a filter straw should be utilised. Filter straws and blunt filter needles should become the accepted practice for the Trust to ensure that practices are as safe and in compliance with regulatory legislation.
Safety-engineered devices
7.9.1 Safety-engineered devices are also known as safer needle devices or safety devices. These have a built-in safety feature to reduce the risk of a sharps injury before, during or after use.
7.9.2 When selecting and evaluating a safety device the following features should be considered:
The device must not compromise patient care;
The device must perform reliably;
The safety mechanism must be an integral part of the safety device, not a separate accessory;
Should be relatively simple to use and require minimal changes to established techniques;
Activation of the device should allow care giver to maintain control over the procedure;
The device should not create added safety hazards or sources of blood exposures.
Single handed activation is preferable;
Activation must be via noticeable manifestion (audible, visual or tactile) to the healthcare professional and be irreversible once activated.
7.9.3 To reduce the risk of inoculation/splash injury the healthcare professioan should:
Utilise needless intravenous devices and safer needle systems whenever possible;
Seek assistance when using sharps with a confused or agitated patient/client;
Exercise caution when handling any waste bags, avoiding close contact with your body to prevent any inappropriately disposed sharps causing injury.
Safe Use of Sharps
7.10.1 Individuals utilising sharps equipment should remain mindful to never underestimate the infectious hazard implications of a sharps injury or accidental splash exposure.

7.10.2 Many sharps injuries can be avoided by following the safe practices as detailed in section above. However, it is recognised that some injuries are unforeseen accidents. It may be possible to reduce risk of sharps associated injury or rate occurrence by introduction correct use of ‘safer sharps'.

7.10.3 It is the responsibility of service managers to ensure staff use of safe sharps deviceswhenever possible. Service managers should consider the supply of safer sharps devices in preference to standard sharps devices wherever possible.

7.10.4 Staff must minimise risks of inoculation injury by treating all body fluids from all patients as potentially infectious. The following steps should be taken to minimise risks when using sharps.
Always wear disposable gloves when handling sharps. NB. Vinyl gloves should not be used for sharps procedures;

IMPORTANT: Never place sharps or needles (including giving sets) into waste bags as this may tear the bag and cause injury to others. The whole device (including any remaining fluids) must be placed inside the sharps container. Attempts should never be made to cut sharps from lines, tubes and fluid bags;
Only ‘in use' sharps bins/sharps equipment should be located in patient areas and should be under the direct supervision of a member of Trust staff trained in sharps management;
Gloves cannot prevent needle stick injuries but they may prevent the acquisition of infection by reducing the volume of blood inoculated during the incident or splashing onto broken skin;
Wear face protection if splashing is likely to occur;
Completely cover breaks in the skin with waterproof dressing.

Used syringes, cartridges and needles must not be re-sheathed, recapped, bent, broken or disassembled after use and must be disposed of directly into a sharps bin at the point of use. Re-sheathing needles is banned by Health and Safety (Sharps Instruments in Healthcare) Regulations;
Never bend, break or attempt to remove a needle from the syringe;
Discard the needle and syringe as a single unit, at point of use and into an appropriate sharps bin;
When the black indicator line (marked on the sharps bin label) is reached the sharps bin be closed permanently (Refer to Appendix 3) to make safe for removal operatives to the waste cart area;
When placing sharps in the container, staff MUST ensure that all contents pass the plastic flap and enter the container;
It is the responsibility of the healthcare worker who uses the 'sharps' to safely dispose of them and avoid exposing others to risk;
Never push down on the contents within a sharps container in an attempt to make more room;

Never pass sharps from person to person for disposal, if possible organise duties to keep sharps handling to a minimum. When hand to hand passage of sharps is unavoidable i.e. During operation procedures or while assisting with procedures on a patient all operatives involved must exercise extreme caution at all times;
Never try to catch a sharp that has been accidently dropped;

Some drugs are only supplied in the form of prefilled multi dose pen devices for patient self-administration. Where the patient is unable to self-administer and there is no alternative solution staff should use the device to administer according to the prescriber's instructions. Where it is necessary to remove the needle to allow for multi dose administration, a suitable needle removal device may be used carefully following manufacturers instruction. Owen Mumford ‘Uniguard' is one preferred device. This is a single use device which is discarded with the removed needle insitu;
Attend the appropriate sharps training and refresher sessions;
Be especially vigilant during emergency and surgical procedures;
Encourage the introduction and use safer sharps devices (refer to Section 5.6) where possible throughout their service;
Report all accidents involving contaminated sharps (and near misses) using the Trust incident reporting system and follow the procedure outlined in Section 5.8.1 following a sharps injury accident;
Unsheathed sharps should not be carried in hands. Sharps taken to a patient's bed side whether in acute ward or patient's home must be transported in a container, tray or trolley;

If a patient displays signs of being overly anxious regarding an invasive procedure, (i.e. when taking blood, giving infusions/injections, the clinician should consider requesting assistance from other operatives, to reduce the risk of inoculation injury.

N.B. Pharmacy Note: Risk assessment for pharmacy preparation of patient specific injectable medications will identify an accepted risk to re-cap/re-sheath pre-prepared injectable medications. When this practice is undertaken tools should be utilised to prevent a pharmacy operative's hand from making contact with the sharp while undertaking the re-sheathing or recapping preparation procedure).
Venepuncture
7.11.1 Taking blood is a potentially hazardous procedure, and wearing gloves is mandatory.

7.11.2 Gloves cannot prevent percutaneous injury but does reduce the risk of acquiring a blood borne- viral infection. Although punctured gloves allow blood to contaminate the hand, the wiping effect of the glove can reduce the volume of blood to which the worker's hand is exposed and also the volume inoculated in the event of a sharps injury.
Use of Sharps Bins

7.12.1 Sharps must only be disposed of in designated sharps containers that meet the requirements of the British Standard: BS 7320 (1990) UN.3291., i.e. with a handle, lid, allow one handed disposal of the used sharp, resist penetration/leakage, bear biological hazard sign.

7.12.2 Ensure that sharps are disposed of in the correct colour coded sharps container (Refer to Appendix 5) Please note sharps used to administer cytotoxic / cytostatic drugs must be disposed of into a purple lidded / purple labelled sharps container). Further guidance is available in the Trust's Waste Disposal policy.
7.12.3 It is the responsibility of the individual who has used the sharp equipment, to safely dispose of it in an appropriate container. Sharps must not be left for others to clear away.
7.12.4 When utilising the vacutainer system for venepuncture, this device must be used in line with the manufacturer's guidelines to reduce the risk of sharps injury.

7.12.5 Place all disposable sharps (as a complete unit ‘needle & syringe') into an approved (BS 7320, UN 3291) puncture proof sharps container immediately at the point of use. The disposal container is colour coded to denote waste stream of contents in line with Trust clinical waste disposal policy / procedures. (Refer to Appendix 5 for waste stream colour codes.
7.12.6 Always ensure that the correct sharps bin is used (appropriate coloured lid) for the segregation and disposal of waste in accordance with the organisation's Waste. Management Policy.
7.12.7 Fill sharps bin to the ‘fill' line only. Never overfill any sharps bin.
7.12.8 Container being transported / carried by healthcare workers must have the TCM in place during transit.(refer to Apprendix 4)

7.12.9 There needs to be a formal risk assessment in place which details a clear procedure for the use of TCM (Temporary closure mechanism) .i.e. container in constant use not required to use the TCM, as this would pose a greater risk to the user. (In the event Trust are called to manage and remove Category A microorganism which fall under UN2814 these are disposed of into a sharps bin. The closed sharps bin is then disposed of in accordance with the emergency security procedure in place to manage Clinical Waste / Patient Belongings Contaminated with ‘Category A' listed Micro- Organisms)
7.12.10 Commonly seen disposable clinical equipment, which require disposal in a sharps container are listed below (list not exhaustive)
Assembly of Sharps Bin
7.13.1 Ensure sharps containers are an appropriate size for the clinical activity-do not select excessively large container, or those that are too small for the size needle/syringe you use.
7.13.2 Staff must ensure the sharps bin is correctly assembled according to manufacturers' instructions.
7.13.3 Ensuring the lid is secured to the entire rim of the base section, (refer to Appendix 3). They should be secured, or placed in a stable safe position to avoid spillage accidents.
7.13.4 Once assembled prior to putting into use, attempt to pull the lid and bin apart to ensure it has been assembled correctly.
7.13.5 Always ensure that the correct sharps bin is used (appropriate coloured lid) for the segregation and disposal of waste in accordance with the organisation's Waste Management Policy.
7.13.6 Staff must ensure traceability of sharps containers in case of adverse incident by labelling the sharps bin at the time of assembly with:
Point of Use / Ward of origin;
Date;
Print Name.
Location of Sharps Bin

7.7.6 Collaboartive Community Staff Utilising Trust Sharps Bins
Healthcare staff who travel in the community and carry sharps (used or unused) in the course of their work should follow a safe system of working at all times.
Community staff should;
Have access to appropriately sized sharps bins compliant with relevant standards.
Arrange removal of sharps bins from patients' homes that are housebound via the Environmental Services Department of the local authority.

When transporting sharps bins from client to client must be undertaken in a responsible and safe manner. Sharps bins must be transported in a rigid, robust container's to avoid accidents occurring and carry at all times the Trust's community Transport Document. Community staff must ensure that sharps boxes are kept out of sight in a locked car.

Alert the waste contractor as soon as possible if a sharps bin has been placed in the incorrect waste stream i.e. a sharps bin placed in a domestic waste (black) bag and collected by the Local Authority. An incident form must be completed.
Dispose of sharps immediately after use in a container suitable for transport, close the lid immediately after use, to the temporary closure point if the bin is to be used again;
Secure the container in the vehicle to avoid tipping;
Follow instructions for the assembly and use of sharps containers, including the use of lid closing and locking mechanisms;
Report any lid closing and locking mechanisms problems so that the suitability of the container can be reviewed;
Check the container at the end of each shift to ensure no sharps have been dropped or spilled in the vehicle.
Report any difficulty following this process to the manager.
Refrain from using the affected area if sharps have been spilled and, if necessary, do not use the whole vehicle until made safe.

Clear contaminated vehicles as soon as possible without compromising safety using a torch, a special tool/device to avoid hand contact, and Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), being wary of sharps hidden in crevices and fabrics.

7.7.8 Patient's Own Sharps

Many patients self-administer medications e.g. people with diabetes. A variety of administration and monitoring systems are available including pens as well as needles, lancets and syringes. All systems involving the use of sharps have the potential to cause injury if handled inappropriately.
Patients self-administering medication must be supervised and trained in safe practices prior to being allowed to self-medicate, including safe disposal.

Staff providing needle exchange to drug users should provide sharps bins and advice on returning these, advice on safer injecting practice and overdose prevention. Where appropriate staff should offer help to stop injecting, immunisation services and referral to drug treatment services.

Appropriate equipment must be provided for the patient either by their GP or hospital consultant/nurse specialist. Small portable sharps bins complying with relevant standards must be used. These must be returned to the patient's GP practice/hospital department if distributed from there for disposal as clinical waste or via Local authority drop off and collection service.
Patient's own sharps bins must not be disposed of into the household waste stream.

A needle is brought to you. If you have a sharps box available the person with the needle should put it in the sharps box. If no box is available, the Health Care Worker should keep the needle safe and arrange non-urgent disposal by the Local Authority.
Needle remains in an accessible public place. Note the exact site of needle(s) and arrange urgent collection by the Local Authority.
Needle remains in a public place but inaccessible e.g. under a drain grate. Note the exact site. Arrange-non urgent collection and disposal by the Local Authority.
If appropriate please complete an incident form via the Trust incident reporting system.
2) If an injury has occurred:
The injured person should be advised to visit one of the MSEEmergency Departments as soon as possible.

7.8.5 Bites and Scratches

Scratches and bites are generally considered as a low risk injury for blood borne viruses. The risks are increased when there is blood present under the nails of a patient who scratches or in the mouth of a patient who bites, otherwise these injuries are deemed as low risk. The HIV virus does not survive well outside of the body and due to the lower infection risk from HIV, the risk of transmission from a scratch is remote.

If the skin is intact following a bite or a scratch then it is impervious to blood borne viruses. However if the skin is not intact following a bite or scratch eg through cuts or abrasions then transmission may occur.
An individual risk assessment should be completed with the manager/supervisor on duty as the staff member affected may not need to attend the local Emergency Department or Occupational Health.
IMMEDIATE ACTION
Gently Wash area liberally with soap and water without scrubbing.
Dry and cover with a waterproof dressing.
7.8.6 Further action to take in relation to percutaneous injuries (needle stick/punctured skin)

Upon gaining consent only (Refer to Appendix 6) , a sample of 10ml-clotted blood is required from both patient (if known) and the staff member. The sample must only be taken by an Occupational Health or Emergency Department operative. On the patient's (source) laboratory form write in the clinical details section “Inoculation injury to (Full needle stick screen / date, time)”.

The patient's sample will be tested (following patien's consent) for the presence of blood- borne viruses (hepatitis B, C or HIV). Under no circumstances should testing be carried out without the patient's informed consent. A careful risk assessment should be carried out on the patient to determine which of these tests are required and, if so, how urgently.
Timing

Timing is important. The patient's blood should be tested as soon as possible following the incident. If they are in a high-risk group, they may require urgent testing. This should be discussed with the Consultant/General Practitioner in charge of the patient's care.
Staff member (recipient)

The staff member must be sent to the nearest Emergency Department at all times, taking details of the patient (if known) from whom they have acquired the injury from. This should include information regarding the patient's history and if they are known to have a blood borne virus or belong to a high risk group (e.g. intravenous drug user, homosexual, originates from high risk country). A sample of blood will be taken, following consent, and the staff at the relevant department will explain what is to happen to the blood and provide support to the staff member.

Hepatitis B Vaccine: Staff who have not been vaccinated against Hepatitis B should be offered an accelerated course as soon as they report the incident, i.e. one dose immediately, further doses at one month, 2 months and  months.
Obtaining consent from the patient
Consent will be required if Hepatitis B, C or HIV testing is necessary. Information for the patient is available in Appendix
If the patient is on a ward/clinic, ask the respective doctor to take the sample (with informed consent).

If the patient is at home the blood sample must be obtained as soon as practicable (with informed consent). The blood sample must include details of the affected staff member as well as the patient's details. The minimum information required will be the staff member's name, date of birth and date of contamination injury.

The Consultant in charge of the patient's care should consider the need for referral to Genito-Urinary Medicine Department for counselling. Any referral should be made by the Consultant in charge of the patient's care.

If the patient belongs to a high-risk group (e.g. intravenous drug user (IVDU), homosexual, originates from high risk country) then consideration needs to be given to testing for other blood-borne viruses, such as Hepatitis B, C and HIV, as prophylactic antiviral therapy may be of benefit. If the patient is known or strongly suspected to be HIV positive.
If the patient is unknown or refuses to give consent to testing the staff member is still required to attend the Emergency Department where a risk assessment will be undertaken.
Reporting the Injury

The member of staff who has been injured must inform their manager or person in charge as soon as possible, a Trust Incident report (on line) should be completed in accordance with Trust incident reporting policy and procedure. All wards and clinical areas will have a “Needlestick Action Pack”. The pack will contain all the information necessary to ensure the correct action is taken. The person in charge along with the member of staff (recipient) will complete “Recipient Needlestick Risk Assessment” form (Refer to appendix 2).This will help determine the likelihood and severity of the exposure incident.
If the injury occurs during core hours (Monday to Friday,  – 4.30)  it  must be reported immediately to Occupational Health & Wellbeing on relevant site number.

If the injury occurred outside of these times, the member of staff must attend Accident and Emergency immediately and then attend Occupational Health & Wellbeing at the earliest opportunity i.e. the following day).

Prompt action is absolutely crucial, especially if the risk assessment indicates that Post Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) is required.  PEP should ideally be administered within the first hour following a significant exposure.
The member of staff will bring the completed risk assessment form with them to either Occupational Health & Wellbeing or A&E

The member of staff will need to have bloods taken for serum save – this can only be undertaken by Occupational Health & Wellbeing or Accident & Emergency to ensure they can be legally validated in accordance with Trust policy.
The bloods must be an identified validated sample (IVS). An IVS is defined as:
the Health Care Worker (HCW) should show proof of identity with photo ID (e.g. Trust ID badge, new driver's license or passport).
the sample should be taken by Occupational Health & Wellbeing or A&E.
the sample should be delivered to the Laboratory in the usual manner, not transported by the HCW.

when the results are received, the clinical notes should be checked for a record that the sample was generated by Occupational Health & Wellbeing (OH) or Emergency Department. (n.B. Microbiology will only authorise samples from OH & Emergency Department.

7.9.1 Exposure Prone Procedures

Exposure Prone Procedures (EPP) are those procedures where ‘there is a risk that injury to the worker may result in the exposure of the patient's open tissues to the blood of the worker'. These procedures include those where the worker's gloved hands may be in contact with sharp instruments, needle tips and sharp tissues (spicules of bone or teeth) inside a patient's open body cavity, wound or confined anatomical space, where the hands or finger tips may not be completely visible at all times. Non EPP - includes taking blood, setting up and maintaining IV lines, minor surface suturing, incision of abscesses, uncomplicated endoscopies or normal vaginal delivery. (UK Health Department, 1993).
There is a low risk of BBV transmission during EPPs as injury to the worker could result in their blood contaminating their patient's open tissues.

All health care workers who will perform EPPs need to have standard health clearance and additional health checks to ensure they are free from infection with hepatitis B, hepatitis C and HIV. This category includes healthcare workers new to the NHS, healthcare workers moving to a post or training post that involves EPP and returning healthcare workers, depending on activities when away from NHS, for example those who may have been exposed to serious communicable diseases, or any potential exposure to a BBV since last IVS check.

Laboratory test results required for clearance for undertaking EPPs must be derived from an identified validated sample (IVS) undertaken by a UK OH department. Results should not be recorded in occupational health records if not derived from an IVS. The health care worker should show a proof of identity with a photograph, for example: Trust identity badge, new driver's licence, a credit card or passport.
7.9.2 Responsibilities of staff when undertaking higher risk procedures

All health care workers are under an overriding ethical, as well as legal duty to protect the health and safety of their patients. Healthcare workers who believe they may have been exposed to infection with HIV, Hepatitis B or Hepatitis C, must seek medical advice via Occupational Health and diagnostic antibody testing if appropriate. Failure to do so may breach their duty of care to patients. In addition refer to Trust Management of HIV infected staff who perform exposure prone procedures policy.

Appendix 1 – Five Steps to Risk Assessment Approach for Sharps Management
Step 1: Identify the hazards
In most hospital and health care environments there will be varying degrees of exposure to blood-borne viruses (BBVs). The main BBVs of concern are hepatitis B and C and HIV.

Accidental injury by a sharp implement, such as a hollow bore needle contaminated with a blood-borne virus, can lead to the transmission of BBVs. While the risks of contracting a blood-borne virus are variable, the anxiety of having to go through blood tests and possible treatment can cause the worker a great deal of stress.
Step 2: Decide who might be harmed and how

The directive and existing regulations cover all workers that are under the managerial authority and supervision of health care employer/ organisations. This extends not only to staff that are directly employed, but also some self-employed workers. For example, agency and bank nurses, any workers employed by organisations contracted to provide services for health care organisations such as cleaners and other ancillary staff. The agreement also covers any students while they are under the supervision of any health care provider.
There are many types of health care and hospital work that can expose individuals to the risk of sharps injuries. They include:
clinical work – clinical procedures such as phlebotomy, cannulation, vaccination, acupuncture and surgical procedures
ancillary services – cleaning, portering, hospital laundry and sterile supplies, medical equipment servicing
diagnostic and laboratory work
mortuary work.

Groups that carry out the majority of procedures using sharps are those most at risk. These include: nurses, operating departmental practitioners (ODPs), phlebotomists, physiotherapists, doctors, health care assistants and laboratory technicians. In addition, cleaning staff will have a high exposure to risks if sharps are not properly disposed of. Community-based, as well as acute staff, may be injured by inappropriate use or non-disposal of sharps. There are also specific environmental regulations in place to cover the disposal of hazardous health care waste such as sharps in a community setting (DH, 2011), UN 3291 which requires hazardous sharps to be appropriately packaged for disposal (Refer to appendix 5)
Injury can occur with a wide range of items, but those with a higher risk of injury include:
hollow bore hypodermic needles
IV cannulae
winged steel needles (butterfly)
phlebotomy needles.
Step 3: evaluate the risks and decide on precautions
The  Hierarchy of controls  on the prevention of sharps injuries (refer to section 5.3) is a way of implementing the law and best practice. The hierarchy is detailed below.
Elimination of hazard
Complete removal of a hazard from the workplace is the most effective way to control hazards; this approach should be used whenever possible. Examples include:
removing sharps and needles when possible e.g. using needleless intravenous systems/ needle free connectors
eliminating all unnecessary injections
eliminating unnecessary sharps such as towel clips.
Engineering controls
These are used to isolate or remove a hazard from a workplace. Examples include:
adequate numbers of easily accessible sharps disposal containers
environmental factors including good lighting and adequate space to carry out the procedure
use of safety-engineered devices for all procedures (devices with needles that retract, sheath or blunt immediately after use).
Administrative controls
These are practices that aim to limit exposure to the hazard. Examples include:
removal of all unsafe devices
safe systems of work, particularly high risk areas such as theatres, obstetrics and emergency care

consistent information and training that includes: safe systems of work; correct use and disposal of sharps; the use of safety-engineered medical devices incorporating sharps protection mechanisms; measures to be taken in the event of a sharps injury; and how to use personal protective equipment provided
incident reporting procedures and investigations that include feedback to staff/ staff groups involved
vaccination programmes and follow up procedures e.g. hepatitis B.
Work practice controls
These controls aim to change the behaviour of workers to reduce exposure to occupational hazards. Examples include:
no needle recapping or re-sheathing – this practice has been banned under Health and Safety (Sharps Instruments in Healthcare) Regulations
safe construction of sharps containers
placing sharps containers at user level and within arms' reach
disposing of sharps immediately after use in designated sharps containers
sealing and discarding sharps containers when the fill line is reached
establishing means for the safe handling and disposal of sharps devices before the beginning of a procedure.
Personal protective equipment (PPE)

Personal protective equipment provides barriers and filters between the worker and the hazard. Used properly it can prevent exposure to blood splashes, but will not prevent needle stick injuries. Examples include:
eye protection
masks
gloves.

There is evidence that gloves can reduce the risk of infection, in particular double-gloving in operating theatres. The glove material will remove up to  per cent of the blood on the outside of the needle, and the inner glove will remove most blood not removed by the outer glove (Mast et al., 1993).
Step 4: record your findings and implement them
The findings of the risk assessment should be documented and form part of the action plan to reduce the risks of injury. (Refer to Appendix 2)
The results of the risk assessment should be shared with all workers identified as being at risk.
Performance indicators such as the increase in the number of safety devices being purchased can be used to ensure that risk assessments are being implemented.
Step 5: review your assessment and update if necessary

Steps should be taken to periodically review the effectiveness of the risk assessment and control measures in place. In addition the risk assessments should also be reviewed if changes take place to work practices or new equipment is introduced.

data.text: Appendix 6 - Patient information following staff/other patient exposure to your blood or body fluids.
Testing information for patients

A member of staff/other patient has been accidentally exposed to your blood or body fluids during the course of their work/treatment. We are requesting to test your blood in order to assist the member of staff/other patient. Three specific viruses are covered in this information sheet. All three viruses can be present in your body without your knowledge. We ask every patient in this situation if we can test him or her for:

HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus): A virus that can be transmitted through blood, body fluids, and sexual exposure. Examples include sharing needles, syringes or equipment for drugs, tattoos, body piercing, through unscreened blood transfusions, and from mother to baby.
Hepatitis B: A virus that affects the liver and is passed on in the same way as HIV.

Hepatitis C: A virus that affects the liver and is usually passed on through blood or sharing needles or other equipment during recreational drug injecting. Other examples include tattoos, body piercing, and unscreened blood transfusions.
Frequently Asked Questions:
What does the test involve? A 5 ml sample of blood will be taken from your arm. If any of the results are positive, the test will be repeated to confirm the result.

Who will know my test result? The result will be given to you in confidence and your own doctor will be informed. The doctor looking after the member of staff/other patient affected will be informed, unless you request otherwise.
What if I am found to have one of these viruses? If the test shows that you have one of these viruses, you will be offered care, support, and treatment.

What are the benefits of having these tests now? You can have these viruses with or without any symptoms. If you have Hepatitis B or Hepatitis C virus, treatment can often help to cure you and reduce the damage to your liver. New treatments are available for individuals with HIV. The treatment for HIV may be more effective if it is given before any serious illness develops.

How can this help the member of staff/other patient who has been exposed to my blood? If you are carrying a blood borne virus the member of staff/other patient affected can be followed up to see if the virus has been transmitted to them and treated if necessary.

Will having the HIV test affect my chances of getting life insurance? Doctors do not need to report negative HIV tests when writing insurance reports. Insurance companies should no longer ask whether you have had an HIV test, they should only ask whether or not you are HIV positive (As agreed by the Association of British Insurers 1994).

What are the drawbacks of having the HIV test? If you do have HIV, the benefits of knowing usually outweigh the disadvantages, which may include difficulties in relationships with family and friends or, for some, employment issues. Travel to some countries is currently restricted for people who know they have HIV.

If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to ask a member of staff. When you have read this information sheet and asked any questions please sign below. You may have a copy of this information sheet.
CONSENT
I fully understand the information given to me and have had the opportunity to ask questions regarding the tests.
I agree/do not agree to have my blood tested for HIV, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C.
